'''Guitar Slim, Jr.''' (born '''Rodney Glynn Armstrong''', 1951, [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[New Orleans blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[singing|singer]]. Over his lengthy playing career, Slim Jr., has worked with various blues [[musician]]s.  His debut [[album]], ''Story of My Life'' (1988), was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]].<ref name="AMG"/> 

==Biography==
His father was the noted blues performer, [[Guitar Slim]], best known for the million-selling song, "[[The Things That I Used to Do]]", that was listed in [[The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll]].<ref name="specialty">{{cite web
|url=http://www.bsnpubs.com/specialty.html
|title=Specialty Album Discography
|publisher=
|accessdate=November 25, 2006 
|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061116145354/http://www.bsnpubs.com/specialty.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = November 16, 2006}}</ref> 

Guitar Slim, Jr., has worked for many years around the New Orleans blues [[nightclub|club]] circuit, and his repertoire became more reliant on his father's material.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p354/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Bill Dahl |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=June 1, 2009}}</ref> His debut album [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] in 1988, ''Story of My Life'', was nominated in [[31st Grammy Awards|1989]] for a [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album]].<ref name="AMG"/> However, New Orleans historian Jeff Hannusch, stated on the [[Liner notes|sleeve notes]] for that album that Slim, Jr., "has been a fixture on the black New Orleans club circuit for the better part of 20 years...[but] doesn't get to play the posher uptown clubs."<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=guitar-slim-jr-p355/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Guitar Slim, Jr. |author=O'Neal, Jim |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=July 26, 2011}}</ref>

Slim, Jr., toured with [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] in the late 1980s, and remained a friend until the latter's death in 1990.
<ref name="Slim">{{cite web |url=http://www.guitarslimjr.com/NewOrleansBlues/Bio.html|title=Guitar Slim, Jr. biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Guitarslimjr.com |accessdate=July 26, 2011}}</ref> Slim's 1996 release, ''Nothing Nice'', featured [[the Memphis Horns]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nothing-nice-r268112/credits |title=''Nothing Nice'' |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=July 26, 2011}}</ref>

Slim's most recent recorded work was the 2010 album release, ''Brought Up The Hardway''.<ref name="Slim"/>

He played at the [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guitarslimjr.com/NewOrleansBlues/Announcements/Entries/2011/5/6_Guitar_Slim%2C_Jr._Rocks_the_Blues_Tent.html |title=New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival 2011 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Guitarslimjr.com |accessdate=July 26, 2011}}</ref>
